org.gannacademy.cdf.graphics.ui

Class AppWindow

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gannacademy.cdf.graphics.ui.AppWindow
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Runnable

    public abstract class AppWindow
extends Object
implements Runnable

    Extendable window controller for DrawingPanel objects

    Extend this class to create your own drawings. Override the abstract method setup() to make your drawing instructions. The recommended approach is to create a new Java class file and to type exactly this (replacing MyDrawingApp with your preferred name, of course):

       public class MyDrawingApp extends AppWindow {}

    This will generate a number of errors in your IDE. Go ahead and let the IDE fix them automagically. The IDE will import the AppWindow class, and then create a method stub for setup(), resulting in something like this:

       import org.gannacademy.cdf.graphics.ui.*;

   public class MyDrawingApp extends AppWindow {
     @Override
     public void setup() {

     }
   }

    Instantiate a MyDrawingApp object to create a window containing your drawing.

    Additional overrideable methods include loop() and done(). loop() will be called repeatedly (inside a loop!) while done() returns false — when done() returns true, the control loop ends (although the application will continue running until the window is closed).

    Author:
    Seth Battis

      • setLocation

        public void setLocation(int x,
                        int y)

        Set the window location on the screen

        The origin of the screen coordinates is the top, left corner with the X-axis increasing from left to right and the Y-axis increasing from top to bottom. All onscreen coordinates are in the first quadrant.

        Parameters:
        x - in pixels
        y - in pixels

        Parameters:

      • run

        public void run()

        Thread execution

        This method is the control loop and should not be called manually (although doing so should have no impact).

        Specified by:
        run in interface Runnable
        See Also:
        loop(), done()

      • setup

        protected abstract void setup()

        Override this method to define your drawing

        This method is called before the window is made visible. All drawing components that need to be rendered at the start of the program run should be defined in this method.

      • loop

        protected void loop()

        Override this method to update drawings in the control loop

        This method represents a single iteration of the control loop. Care should be taken to avoid writing blocking code in this method (e.g. for loops designed to animate a single object) — rather, drawing components should be adjusted based on the values of instance variables, whose values are changed incrementally in each call to this method. For example:

           private double x, y;
   private Rectangle r;

   // setup() and other methods…

   @Override
   public void loop() {
     x += 1;
     y = 20 * Math.sin(x * 20);
     r.moveTo(x, y);
   }

        The above code animates a rectangle moving elegantly in a sine wave (scaled up 20×)across the window.

      • done

        protected boolean done()

        Override this method to set the condition that ends the control loop

        By default, this method will always return false, so that the control loop runs indefinitely.

        Returns:
        true if the control loop should end, false otherwise

      • getDrawingPanel

        public DrawingPanel getDrawingPanel()

        Access the DrawingPanel object contained in this window

        All drawing instructions require a drawing panel on which to execute them. This is the default drawing panel.

        Returns:
        The drawing panel in this window
